finding: The SNP rs6714660 was associated with cardiac ATP metabolism levels in cardiomyocytes. Specifically, it was identified within the context of the AGAP1 gene, which plays a crucial role in cardiac ATP production during the Krebs cycle. The association was determined through analysis of variants in correlation with ATP metabolic scores, indicating a significant relationship between this SNP and myocardial function.
title: Monopogen: single nucleotide variant calling from single cell sequencing

finding: SNP rs62148129 was also reported as overlapping with cEnhancers related to schizophrenia risk. Similar to rs10860964, it interacted with SCZ example genes and contributed to the understanding of fetal origins of adult diseases by revealing how developmental interactions may inform adult disease susceptibility.
title: Integrative analysis of the 3D genome and epigenome in mouse embryonic tissues

finding: This SNP was found in association with EIF2AK3 and registered a p-value of 0.03 in relation to PART, indicating a significant genetic contribution to the risk of tau pathology.
title: Genome-wide association study and functional validation implicates JADE1 in tauopathy

finding: The deletion variant rs56350804 was identified as a significant variant with a posterior inclusion probability of 0.9998. This SNP was shown to be intronic to the SH3YL1 gene and had been linked to significant expression quantitative trait loci (eQTL) effects on the expression of SH3YL1, ACP1, and notably, ALKAL2. In cervical spinal cord tissue, rs56350804 significantly modulated the expression of ALKAL2 (p=3.0×10−16). Notably, the Drosophila homolog of ALKAL2, Alk, had been previously shown to extend lifespan when inhibited, indicating a potential role for ALKAL2 in visual function.
title: Longitudinal fundus imaging and its genome-wide association analysis provide evidence for a human retinal aging clock

finding: rs309137 was associated with chromatin looping interactions with the CXCR4 promoter and was part of a set of significant variants that affected blood CD34+ cell levels, exhibiting a strong regulatory role.
title: Genome-wide association study on 13,167 individuals identifies regulators of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell levels in human blood

finding: rs11688530 showed significant association with regulatory variants near the CXCR4 promoter, indicating its influence on blood CD34+ cell levels, along with other common variants.
title: Genome-wide association study on 13,167 individuals identifies regulators of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell levels in human blood

finding: Similar to rs309137, rs10193623 was identified as having chromatin looping interactions with the CXCR4 promoter, making it a significant variant affecting CD34+ cell levels.
title: Genome-wide association study on 13,167 individuals identifies regulators of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell levels in human blood

finding: rs555647251, a rare variant, showed significant heterogeneity in association results between blood donor and primary care patient populations, suggesting differential impacts on blood disorders.
title: Genome-wide association study on 13,167 individuals identifies regulators of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell levels in human blood

finding: This variant was identified as a regulatory promoter variant located upstream of the CXCR4 transcription start site, contributing to the regulation of blood CD34+ cell levels.
title: Genome-wide association study on 13,167 individuals identifies regulators of hematopoietic stem and progenitor cell levels in human blood

finding: The SNP was identified as newly significant after re-weighting and replicated in UK Biobank data.
title: Leveraging auxiliary data from arbitrary distributions to boost GWAS discovery with Flexible cFDR

finding: Identified as a protective variant in IFIH1 (p.Asn160Asp), rs75671397 had a MAF of 0.002 and an odds ratio of 0.32, indicating its significant association with reduced risk for T1D.
title: Large-scale genetic association and single cell accessible chromatin mapping defines cell type-specific mechanisms of type 1 diabetes risk

finding: The variant rs3087243 showed a PPA of 0.99 and was located in an acinar-specific cCRE, while also being broadly accessible in regulatory T cells, which reflects a specialized function in immune regulation related to T1D.
title: Large-scale genetic association and single cell accessible chromatin mapping defines cell type-specific mechanisms of type 1 diabetes risk

finding: The study established that the homozygous genotypes AA and GG of Ala307Thr (rs6165) in the FSHR gene were the most common in cases of primary amenorrhea (PA), while the homozygous genotype AA was more frequently observed in secondary amenorrhea (SA). Allele A was identified as an etiological factor associated with PA and SA, while allele G acted as a protective factor, indicating significant implications for the genetic understanding of these conditions.
title: Cytogenetic screening of chromosomal abnormalities and genetic analysis of FSH receptor Ala307Thr and Ser680Asn genes in amenorrheic patients

finding: Results indicated that the homozygous genotype GG and the heterozygous genotype AG of Ser680Asn (rs6166) were more prevalent in both PA and SA patients compared to healthy controls. Furthermore, allele G demonstrated a markedly significant positive association with both forms of amenorrhea, whereas allele A was associated negatively, suggesting it could serve as a protective allele in the context of the diseases.
title: Cytogenetic screening of chromosomal abnormalities and genetic analysis of FSH receptor Ala307Thr and Ser680Asn genes in amenorrheic patients

finding: The COL4A3 (rs55703767) gene polymorphism was found to be associated with susceptibility to type 2 diabetes, marking its potential as a risk factor for the disease.
title: Identification of Key Genes and Underlying Mechanisms in Cystic Fibrosis and its Associated Complications Based on Bioinformatics Analysis of Next Generation Sequencing Data Analysis

finding: Polymorphisms of SLC11A1 (NRAMP1) rs17235409 were associated with susceptibility to spinal tuberculosis in a southern Han Chinese population, indicating its significance in infectious diseases.
title: Identification of Key Genes and Underlying Mechanisms in Cystic Fibrosis and its Associated Complications Based on Bioinformatics Analysis of Next Generation Sequencing Data Analysis

finding: The SNP rs17705608, located in the TANK gene, was associated with breast cancer risk. It suggested a link between genetic predisposition and the inflammatory response mediated through NF-κB signal transduction, which plays a crucial role in recurrent disease free outcomes.
title: Integration of multi-omics data shows downregulation of mismatch repair, purin, and tublin pathways in AR-negative triple-negative chemotherapy-resistant breast tumors

finding: The SNP rs7309, also within the TANK gene, was similarly associated with breast cancer risk. Like rs17705608, it emphasized the significance of TANK in TNF-mediated signaling pathways, implicating inflammation in the context of breast cancer recurrence.
title: Integration of multi-omics data shows downregulation of mismatch repair, purin, and tublin pathways in AR-negative triple-negative chemotherapy-resistant breast tumors

finding: The 'A' allele of the cis-eQTL/reQTL (rs13034664) in PHA-stimulated T cells was associated with lower CCL20 expression and increased risk of childhood-onset asthma, thus illustrating the SNP's importance in asthma pathophysiology.
title: Neonatal genetics of gene expression reveal the origins of autoimmune and allergic disease risk

finding: Situated near PAX3, this SNP demonstrated regulatory effects that impacted facial traits, specifically related to nasal positioning.
title: Novel genetic loci affecting facial shape variation in humans

finding: Part of the PAX3 region, this SNP exhibited significant enhancer activity influencing facial morphology.
title: Novel genetic loci affecting facial shape variation in humans

finding: Located in the PAX3 region, this SNP was associated with enhancer activity that impacted facial dimensions.
title: Novel genetic loci affecting facial shape variation in humans

finding: The rs2304672 SNP was found to moderate circadian-relevant reward circuitry activity, particularly in adolescents. This finding was significant as it linked genetic variation to alterations in the molecular rhythms associated with opioid addiction and the dysregulation of sleep and circadian patterns observed in OUD.
title: Molecular rhythm alterations in prefrontal cortex and nucleus accumbens associated with opioid use disorder

finding: Similar to rs11210871, this SNP was linked to higher intelligence and cognitive performance, with the allele associated with better cognitive markers correlating with increased FFQ participation.
title: Genetic predictors of participation in optional components of UK Biobank

finding: The CREB1 gene variant rs6740584 was linked to type 2 diabetes mellitus, emphasizing its significance in metabolic regulation.
title: Identification of key genes and signaling pathway in the pathogenesis of Huntington’s disease via bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: The SNP rs17235409 in SLC11A1 showed a significant interaction with the L4-Ugandan lineage, with a meta-analysis p-value of 0.0002. The ancestral allele (GG) in conjunction with the L4.6 lineage was associated with increased TB severity, indicating a complex interplay influenced by both genetic and lineage factors.
title: Interaction between host genes and M. tuberculosis lineage can affect tuberculosis severity: evidence for coevolution

finding: The SNP rs187943382 caused a V220A mutation in the MATN3 gene. It was identified in the healthy allele of a patient with a MATN3 T120M mutation, which resulted in severe ER stress and skeletal abnormalities. Although the V220A mutation was found in healthy controls as well, it was suggested that it could potentially exacerbate the existing pathology from T120M, which is associated with spondyloepimetaphyseal dysplasia, matrilin 3 type (SEMD-MATN3). The study proposed that while the V220A mutation did not independently cause pathology, it might worsen the effects of the more severe T120M mutation.
title: Human iPSC-derived hypertrophic chondrocytes reveal a mutation-specific unfolded protein response in chondrodysplasias

finding: The SNP rs584542, located at chr2:21232803:T>C, was identified as part of a recurring dinucleotide variant in the APOB gene. This SNP was validated as a germline variant through orthogonal whole-exome sequencing and was present in the panel of normals (PoN), thereby being successfully filtered out during the analysis.
title: PipeIT2: A tumor-only somatic variant calling workflow for Molecular Diagnostic Ion Torrent sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs1041968, found at chr2:21232804:G>A, was determined to be a distinct variant arising from a previously identified recurring dinucleotide variant in APOB. Like rs584542, this SNP was confirmed as a germline variant via orthogonal whole-exome sequencing and was part of the PoN, leading to its successful exclusion in the analysis.
title: PipeIT2: A tumor-only somatic variant calling workflow for Molecular Diagnostic Ion Torrent sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs13020328 was associated with the expression of SerpinB3, which is elevated in glioblastoma (GBM) cancer stem cells (CSCs). This SNP was found to play a role in protecting CSCs against lysosomal-mediated cell death, contributing to therapeutic resistance in GBM. The study indicated that targeting SerpinB3 could enhance the efficacy of radiation therapy in pre-clinical GBM models, thereby suggesting that the presence of this SNP could influence treatment outcomes in patients.
title: SerpinB3 drives cancer stem cell survival in glioblastoma

finding: The SNP rs13010131 was linked to immune checkpoint-related gene expression alterations that were identified in the context of bladder cancer, specifically in the response to schistosomiasis infection by <italic>S. haematobium</italic>. This finding related to the inflammatory response and immune regulation associated with bladder cancer.
title: RNA-seq gene expression profiling of the bladder in a mouse model of urogenital schistosomiasis

finding: The SNP rs6733839:C>T was associated with a significant change in chromatin accessibility in both microglia and induced pluripotent stem cell derived macrophages, with a highly specific cell type association at the BIN1 locus in relation to Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk.
title: A map of transcriptional heterogeneity and regulatory variation in human microglia

finding: Although highly suggestive, rs16866419 was identified as a pQTL for MUC5AC protein concentration, representing a relevant genetic variant associated with mucin levels in COPD.
title: Genetic Regulators of Sputum Mucin Concentration and Their Associations with COPD Phenotypes

finding: Association was reported between the GCKR SNP rs780094 and metabolic traits as well as incident diabetes and cardiovascular disease in the context of the ARIC Study.
title: Identification and Interaction Analysis of Molecular Markers in Myocardial Infarction by Integrated Bioinformatics Analysis

finding: The SNP rs7589901, an intronic variant within the PAX8 gene, was associated with increased chromatin accessibility at its peak. The reference allele A was linked to this increase, suggesting a mechanism by which ZNF135 might act as a transcriptional repressor at this locus. Furthermore, the direction of effect for eQTL and caQTL in GTEx was concordant, indicating that greater chromatin accessibility corresponded with higher expression of PAX8 in whole blood.
title: Genotype inference from aggregated chromatin accessibility data reveals genetic regulatory mechanisms

finding: The SNP rs7421852, situated approximately 3,000 bp from rs7589901, was identified as the lead variant in a GWAS for blood urea levels. It showed strong linkage disequilibrium (r²=0.85) with rs7589901 in the caQTL sample genotype. This suggests that both SNPs may share a mechanistic pathway where decreased ZNF135 binding at these variants leads to increased expression of PAX8 and consequently lower blood urea concentrations.
title: Genotype inference from aggregated chromatin accessibility data reveals genetic regulatory mechanisms

finding: This SNP showed association with greater than 5 CpGs located within the gene body of ADCY3, indicating its possible role in gene regulation related to inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
title: Methylation Quantitative Trait Loci are Largely Consistent across Disease States in Crohn’s disease

finding: The variant rs13021737 was noted to introduce horizontal pleiotropy, showing a positive causal effect with small standard error. This SNP was among those that affected causal estimates and indicated that associations involving BMI and physical activity might not be purely causal.
title: Mendelian randomization suggests a bidirectional, causal relationship between physical inactivity and obesity

finding: The −13910:C<italic>></italic>T polymorphism was strongly associated with lactase persistence (LP) in populations of European ancestry, having been under strong recent selection and likely co-evolving with dairy farming.
title: The genetic variation of lactase persistence alleles in northeast Africa

finding: The −13915:T<italic>></italic>G variant was reported to likely have Middle Eastern origins, associated with LP in the context of recent gene-flow to Sudanese populations.
title: The genetic variation of lactase persistence alleles in northeast Africa

finding: The −14009:T<italic>></italic>G variant occurred at the highest frequency among the investigated populations, indicating its significance in lactase persistence in African Arab groups.
title: The genetic variation of lactase persistence alleles in northeast Africa

finding: The −14010:G<italic>></italic>C variant was shown to have evidence of a selective sweep in African pastoralist populations, linking it to enhanced fitness for individuals with LP.
title: The genetic variation of lactase persistence alleles in northeast Africa

finding: The −14011:G<italic>></italic>A allele was shown to influence promoter activity in vitro, linking it to potential lactase expression in certain populations.
title: The genetic variation of lactase persistence alleles in northeast Africa

finding: The SNP rs13394744 (A>T) was associated with changes in alternative polyadenylation (APA) of the gene ANKMY1, specifically affecting the internal polyadenylation (IPA). Individuals carrying the A/A homozygous genotype exhibited higher expression of the IPA region compared to those with heterozygous A/T or homozygous T/T genotypes. A correlation analysis demonstrated that increased IPA was inversely related to overall gene expression, with a Pearson correlation of r=-0.51 across 17 human tissues. The CRISPRpas method was employed to manipulate isoform ratios in HEK293T dCas9 cells, where an increase in the IPA/FL isoform ratio resulted in decreased full-length transcript expression, further supporting the role of this SNP in APA-related gene regulation.
title: CRISPRpas: Programmable regulation of alternative polyadenylation by dCas9

finding: This SNP was recently found to be associated with eyebrow thickness and facial morphology in Eurasians.
title: How to choose sets of ancestry informative markers: A supervised feature selection approach

finding: The rs1191684 SNP in the PAX8 gene was identified in Europeans and replicated in a cohort of African-American individuals with a p-value of 9.3 × 10^-4, indicating its significance in sleep duration.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide analysis identifies common genetic variants for self-reported sleep duration and shared genetic effects

finding: The minor allele of rs6737318 (PAX8) was associated with similar effects on sleep duration across various ancestry groups. In the AFR cohort, it showed a significant effect of 7.86 minutes per allele with a p-value of 7.3 × 10^-4.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide analysis identifies common genetic variants for self-reported sleep duration and shared genetic effects

finding: The signal for rs7556815 (PAX8) was concordant across all studied populations, indicating robust transferability of this genetic signal related to sleep duration.
title: Multi-ancestry genome-wide analysis identifies common genetic variants for self-reported sleep duration and shared genetic effects

finding: The SNP rs2042138 was found to be linked to a hypoxia-induced metabolic switch that contributes to increased aggressiveness in pancreatic cancer, suggesting its role in enhancing tumor progression associated with EMT under hypoxic conditions.
title: A histone methylation-MAPK signaling axis drives durable epithelial-mesenchymal transition in hypoxic pancreas cancer

finding: The SNP rs4988235 at MCM6/LCT was previously shown to be under selection in West Eurasians. This finding related to lactase persistence, which is the ability to digest lactose in adulthood, highlighting the evolutionary adaptation connected to dairy consumption.
title: Ancestral contributions to contemporary European complex traits

finding: The SNP rs1260326 was identified as having the smallest single SNP p-value of 3.3e-6 in the analyses, indicating a significant association. It was noted that this missense variant is located in the GCKR gene, which had previously been associated with alcohol consumption. Additionally, the interaction between variants in GCKR and alcohol consumption has been reported specifically in relation to gout disease, emphasizing the relevance of this SNP in potential gene-environment interactions.
title: Large-scale multivariate multi-ancestry Interaction analyses point towards different genetic mechanisms by population and exposure

finding: This SNP was recognized as another rare variant tied to African ancestry, demonstrating significance in the pooled analysis.
title: Cloud gazing: demonstrating paths for unlocking the value of cloud genomics through cross-cohort analysis

finding: This variant was associated with American ancestry and showed significance in the pooled analysis.
title: Cloud gazing: demonstrating paths for unlocking the value of cloud genomics through cross-cohort analysis

finding: The SNP rs13020190 was associated with the cold shock protein (CSP) family in Pucciniales. This finding indicated that CSPs played a significant role in the dormancy exit during the life cycle of poplar rust fungus, specifically noted for their enhanced expression after the overwintering stage. The study showcased their importance in environmental responses, supporting their function through heterologous expression in yeast which improved cell growth after cold stress exposure.
title: Expert annotation and life-cycle transcriptomics of transcription factors in rust fungi (Pucciniales) highlight the role of cold shock proteins in dormancy exit

finding: The CCL20 gene variant rs111781203 was reported to decrease the risk of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). In the context of the study, this SNP was noted to be highly upregulated in the novel LND cell type identified in Crohn's disease, indicating its significance in the disease's immune response.
title: A Specialized Epithelial Cell Type Regulating Mucosal Immunity and Driving Human Crohn’s Disease

finding: The SNP <italic>rs1260326</italic> at the <italic>GCKR</italic> locus was highlighted as the maximally associated variant influencing serum urate levels.
title: Genomic dissection of 43 serum urate-associated loci provides multiple insights into molecular mechanisms of urate control
